pullRequest.title: Prevent inlining for "super" captures in RewriteAsyncFunctions

node.title: Super inside an async method does not produce valid ES2015 output
node.bodyHTML:
Using a language out of ECMASCRIPT_2015, the following code produces invalid output.

Original:

class Foo {
  async bar() {
    console.log('bar');
  }
}

class Baz extends Foo {
  async bar() {
    await Promise.resolve();
    super.bar();
  }
}

Compiled with:

java -jar compiler.jar -O=SIMPLE --language_out=ECMASCRIPT_2015 \
    --renaming=false --formatting=PRETTY_PRINT --js test.js

Produces:

// Generator polyfills ...
class Foo {
  bar() {
    return $jscomp.asyncExecutePromiseGeneratorFunction(function*() {
      console.log("bar");
    });
  }
}
class Baz extends Foo {
  bar() {
    const $jscomp$async$this = this;
    return $jscomp.asyncExecutePromiseGeneratorFunction(function*() {
      yield Promise.resolve();
      super.bar.call($jscomp$async$this); // super is not a valid keyword here
    });
  }
}

pullRequest.title: Support multiline ES6 import statements

node.title: Support multiline ES6 `export ... from` syntax
node.bodyHTML:
Description of problem

When parsing ES6 code of the form export ... from, the compiler fails to generate the correct goog.require statement.

Steps to reproduce

Given the following files:

//greet.js
export default function greet(m) {
    document.write("\nHello, " + m);
};
//hello.js
export {
    default as helloGreet
} from "./greet";

Execute:

java -jar $JAR -O BUNDLE --formatting PRETTY_PRINT --module_resolution NODE --js_output_file=/dev/stdout -W VERBOSE --debug --dependency_mode STRICT --entry_point hello.js greet.js hello.js | grep -A 11 -E 'greet|hello'

Expected outcome

Closure compiler should detect greet.js as a dependency of hello.js and output them both under strict dependency mode.

//greet.js
$jscomp.registerAndLoadModule(function($$require, $$exports, $$module) {
  "use strict";
  Object.defineProperties($$exports, {"default":{enumerable:true, get:function() {
    return greet;
  }}});
  function greet(m) {
    document.write("\nHello, " + m);
  }
}, "greet.js", []);

//hello.js
$jscomp.registerAndLoadModule(function($$require, $$exports, $$module) {
  "use strict";
  Object.defineProperties($$exports, {helloGreet:{enumerable:true, get:function() {
    return module$greet["default"];
  }}});
  var module$greet = $$require("greet.js");
}, "hello.js", ["greet.js"]);

Actual outcome

JsFileParser fails compute the list of requires.

//hello.js
$jscomp.registerAndLoadModule(function($$require, $$exports, $$module) {
  "use strict";
  Object.defineProperties($$exports, {helloGreet:{enumerable:true, get:function() {
    return module$greet["default"];
  }}});
  var module$greet = $$require("greet.js");
}, "hello.js", ["greet.js"]);

Workaround/patches

Condensing the export to a single line works around the issue but may be infeasible for third party libs (e.g. from NPM).

Avoiding JsFileParser also fixes the problem:

diff --git a/src/com/google/javascript/jscomp/CompilerInput.java b/src/com/google/javascript/jscomp/CompilerInput.java
index 62609562b..4e4d3e3dc 100644
--- a/src/com/google/javascript/jscomp/CompilerInput.java
+++ b/src/com/google/javascript/jscomp/CompilerInput.java
@@ -285,7 +285,7 @@ public class CompilerInput extends DependencyInfo.Base implements SourceAst {
 
     // If the code is a JsAst, then it was originally JS code, and is compatible with the
     // regex-based parsing of JsFileParser.
-    if (ast instanceof JsAst && JsFileParser.isSupported()) {
+    if (false && ast instanceof JsAst && JsFileParser.isSupported()) {
       // Look at the source code.
       // Note: it's OK to use getName() instead of
       // getPathRelativeToClosureBase() here because we're not using

Analysis

Due to the line parsing nature of JsFileParser, it fails to look ahead when faced with a line that starts with export (or import) but doesn't contain a semicolon. In fact, under shortcut mode, it appears to halt the parser.

pullRequest.title: Ensure that the error constants in MediaError are correctly annotated

node.title: MediaError static fields uses Doubles and does not have defined constants
node.bodyHTML:
We cannot switch on MediaError as it has doubles for the static fields, instead of ints.

Also the actual values are not assigned as constants, which also means it cannot be used in a switch statement.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MediaError

pullRequest.title: Update Window.prototype.scrollTo extern to accept dictionary options

node.title: Update window.scroll signature to accept an options object
node.bodyHTML:
There is an alternative way of using window.scroll (and window.scrollTo) that allows to pass an object instead of the x and y coordinates.

See the MDN docs for reference.

A change in the externs is needed around these lines:

closure-compiler/externs/browser/w3c_css.js

Lines 2099 to 2113 in 964833f

/**
* @param {number} x
* @param {number} y
* @see http://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-view/#dom-window-scroll
* @return {undefined}
*/
Window.prototype.scroll = function(x, y) {};
/**
* @param {number} x
* @param {number} y
* @see http://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-view/#dom-window-scrollto
* @return {undefined}
*/
Window.prototype.scrollTo = function(x, y) {};

I'd be happy to help with a PR, if given some assistance in writing the externs correctly.

pullRequest.title: Fix printing of comma operators in object literals.

node.title: Comma operator is not correctly wrapped in () in object literals (computed keys and values)
node.bodyHTML:
Comma operators in the computed keys or in the values of an object literal are not correctly printed back to JavaScript source. They miss appropriate surrounding parentheses, causing ParseErrors. This happens even in whitespace-only mode.

Reproduction:

// ==ClosureCompiler==
// @compilation_level WHITESPACE_ONLY
// @output_file_name default.js
// @language_out ECMASCRIPT_2015
// @formatting pretty_print
// ==/ClosureCompiler==

function foo() {
  let array = [];
  const x = {
    [(array.push(1), "foo")]: (array.push(2), 3),
    [(array.push(3), "bar")]: (array.push(4), "foobar")
  };
  console.log(array);
  console.log(x);
}

foo(); foo();

is compiled with the above options as:

'use strict';
function foo() {
  let array = [];
  const x = {[array.push(1), "foo"]:array.push(2), 3, [array.push(3), "bar"]:array.push(4), "foobar"};
  console.log(array);
  console.log(x);
}
foo();
foo();

Appspot link

Note the following problems:

  • In a computed key: [array.push(1), "foo"] should be [(array.push(1), "foo")]
  • In a value: array.push(2), 3 should be (array.push(2), 3)

The problem can be reproduced

  • with or without pretty-printing,
  • in WHITESPACE_ONLY, SIMPLE_OPTIMIZATIONS and ADVANCED_OPTIMIZATIONS,
  • tested with version v20190415

pullRequest.title: Move Element.prototype.id to w3c_dom1.js

node.title: Element.id incorrectly declared in HTMLElement
node.bodyHTML:
Version: 1.0.0-RC1

HTMLElement should inherit id from Element. In Closure externs, Element.id is found at gecko_dom.js:756, HTMLElement.id is found at w3c_dom2.js:416.

Comments in gecko_dom suggest that id is defined on HTMLElement and SVGElement separately, but this is no longer true.

pullRequest.title: Stop issuing global this warning for function with this type annotation

node.title: dangerous use of the global this object when function's type was annotated
node.bodyHTML:
I'm trying to make the function to have this by defining it in its type.

/**
 * @type {function(this:{hello:string})}
 */
function test() {
  console.log(this.hello)
}

test.call({ hello: 'world' })

However, I get an error. Is this meant to happen despite me giving the hint as to what this is going to be ?

t/this.js:5: WARNING - dangerous use of the global this object
  console.log(this.hello)
              ^^^^

0 error(s), 1 warning(s), 100.0% typed

Basically my function must adhere to an interface but can have a custom this. When i define it like

/**
 * @this {{hello:string}}
 * @type {_functionInterface}
 */
function test() {
  console.log(this.hello)
}

I get another error because the annotations are incompatible (can't use 2 together). Just have to suppress the globalThis for now.

pullRequest.title: Allow recursive union type definitions

node.title: Stack overflow when using recursive type in combination with Array.prototype.map
node.bodyHTML:
I get a stack overflow error when using a recursive type with Array.prototype.map.

If I replace the .map call with a loop that builds up the args in the makeJsFunctionCall function below, then the error goes away.

Tested locally and with appspot.

// ==ClosureCompiler==
// @compilation_level ADVANCED_OPTIMIZATIONS
// @output_file_name default.js
// ==/ClosureCompiler==

/**
 * @typedef {(string|number|boolean|null)}
**/
var JsonPrimitiveType;

/**
 * @typedef {Object<string,JsonType>!}
**/
var JsonObjectType;

/**
 * @typedef {Array<JsonType>!}
**/
var JsonArrayType;

/**
 * @typedef {(JsonPrimitiveType|JsonObjectType|JsonArrayType)}
**/
var JsonType;

/**
 * @param {string} func
 * @param {Array<JsonType>!} args
 * @return {string}
**/
function makeJsFunctionCall (func, args) {
	var inner = args.map(function (x) { return JSON.stringify(x); });
	return func + "(" + inner.join(", ") + ")";
}

It produces this error:

23: java.lang.StackOverflowError
at com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype.UnknownType.isSubtype(UnknownType.java:121)
at com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype.UnknownType.isSubtype(UnknownType.java:115)
at com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype.JSType.isSubtypeOf(JSType.java:1748)
at com.google.javascript.jscomp.TypeInference.maybeResolveTemplatedType(TypeInference.java:1483)
at com.google.javascript.jscomp.TypeInference.maybeResolveTemplatedType(TypeInference.java:1432)
at com.google.javascript.jscomp.TypeInference.maybeResolveTemplatedType(TypeInference.java:1492)
... many lines removed ...

pullRequest.title: Move the standardized focus management APIs to html5.js

node.title: activeElement is missing from Document
node.bodyHTML:
Elemental2 version : 1.0.0-RC1
The document object provide by DomGloabl does not have the activeElement property
as a workaround i extended the HTMLDocument type and added the property and it worked out

@JsType(isNative = true, namespace = JsPackage.GLOBAL)
public class MyDocument extends HTMLDocument {
    public Element activeElement;
}

checking this out on MDN it says it is supported by most of modern browsers.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DocumentOrShadowRoot/activeElement

pullRequest.title: Switches CommonJS modules to use the module metadata map

node.title: CommonJS compatibility does not work as expected
node.bodyHTML:
The compiler puts each commonJs module into default property of the imported object.

// ecma
import commonJs from './common-js'

console.log('requiring a common js from ecma:')
console.log(commonJs)
CommonJS From ECMACommonJS From CommonJS
// common-js.js
const commonJs2 = require('./common-js2')

module.exports = () => {
  console.log('default common js export')
}
module.exports['named'] = () => {
  console.log('named common js export')
}

console.log('requiring a ' +
'common js from common js:')
console.log(commonJs2)
 
// common-js2.js
module.exports = () => {
  console.log('default common js ' 
+ 'export2')
}
module.exports['named'] = () => {
  console.log('named common js ' 
+ 'export2')
}

Run the compiler

java -jar /Users/zavr/node_modules/google-closure-compiler-java/compiler.jar \
--compilation_level ADVANCED --language_out ECMASCRIPT_2017 --formatting PRETTY_PRINT \
--process_common_js_modules --entry_point \
example/commonjs/index.js --module_resolution NODE --js \
example/commonjs/index.js example/commonjs/common-js.js example/commonjs/common-js2.js

Get the output

'use strict';
var a = () => {
  console.log("default common js export2");
};
a.named = () => {
  console.log("named common js export2");
};
var b = {default:() => {
  console.log("default common js export");
}};
b.default.named = () => {
  console.log("named common js export");
};
console.log("requiring a common js from common js:");
console.log(a);
console.log("requiring a common js from ecma:");
console.log(b);

Execute the output

requiring a common js from common js:
{ [Function: a] named: [Function] }
requiring a common js from ecma:
{ default: { [Function: default] named: [Function] } }

This does not make sense. I shouldn't write .default as confirmed here #3308. When it comes to Babel-compiled modules, it's a nightmare. Babel exports { default: code } itself, so the currently closure-compatible code becomes

import erte from '@a-la/fixture-babel'

console.log(erte.default.default())
console.log(erte.default.c())
console.log(erte.default.b())

And if you actually try to execute in with babel, you get

console.log(_.default.default.default());
                              ^

TypeError: Cannot read property 'default' of undefined

Developers developers developers developers
Babel Babel Babel Babel
Default Default Default Default

pullRequest.title: Remove the non-standard parameter opt_distance from History.prototype.back

node.title: opt_distance parameter in function definition for History.prototype.back
node.bodyHTML:
In pull request #3330, the opt_distance parameter was included in the function definition for History.prototype.back

https://github.com/google/closure-compiler/blob/v20190528/externs/browser/html5.js#L3154

/**
 * Goes back one step in the joint session history.
 * If there is no previous page, does nothing.
 *
 * @return {undefined}
 */
History.prototype.back = function(opt_distance) {};

This causes the following warning when calling History.prototype.back with zero arguments

WARNING - [JSC_WRONG_ARGUMENT_COUNT]
Function History.prototype.back: called with 0 argument(s).
Function requires at least 1 argument(s) and no more than 1 argument(s).

pullRequest.title: Move webassembly.js from "contrib" to "browser"

node.title: WebAssembly externs likely incorrectly located in "contrib"
node.bodyHTML:
As noted in #2533 by @RReverser:

An up-to-date Closure Compiler is complaining about variable WebAssembly being undeclared.
Is it because externs are in contrib/externs/... as opposed to externs/browser/... where they were added initially in a PR #2534? All the other APIs in contrib/externs/... seem to be for 3rd-party libs, whereas WebAssembly is a stable API available in all browsers, seems weird that it's not colocated with other standard APIs.

pullRequest.title: Add optimization to replace `Array.of` with an array literal

nodes.message:
Adding trailing comma property to object literal node

PiperOrigin-RevId: 307701367
Add enableNormalize

node.title: Array.of can be optimized
node.bodyHTML:
The compiler should always be able to optimize Array.of to [] when language_out is ES6. Is this something that can be added?

Example:

function arrayOf(...values) {
    return Array.of(...values);
}
console.log(arrayOf(1, 2, 3));
$ closure-compiler --language_out ES6 --compilation_level ADVANCED array_of.js

Output (v20200224):

'use strict';console.log(Array.of(...[1,2,3]));

Expected output:

'use strict';console.log([1,2,3]);

node.title: Path2D externs definition is missing optional constructor arguments
node.bodyHTML:
The Path2D constructor has an optional argument that is either a string or another Path2D object: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Path2D/Path2D

The externs are currently missing this https://github.com/google/closure-compiler/blob/master/externs/browser/html5.js#L264

Version: any version of Closure.

pullRequest.title: feat: add full Unicode support for Javascript identifiers

node.title: Parser error on "combining character" (U+0307)
node.bodyHTML:
There seems to be an issue with parsing composite character sequences.

Composite character I consist of the base character and combining character sequence (U+0049)(U+0307)
Using this character causing the compiler to fail with the parser error.

Example code

var bar = {
I: "foo"
};

Compiler error

input0:2: ERROR - [JSC_PARSE_ERROR] Parse error. Character '' (U+0307) is not a valid identifier start char
  2| I: "foo"
      ^

1 error(s), 0 warning(s)

Demo

Example

pullRequest.title: Prevent arrow functions from being improperly inlined

mergeCommit.message:
Merge pull request #3757 from DavidANeil:davidneil-no-inline-arrows

PiperOrigin-RevId: 353083185

nodes.message:
Fixes RTCPeerConnectionIceEvent externs to make it extend Event.

PiperOrigin-RevId: 353068060

Prevent arrow functions from being improperly inlined

Closes #3756.

node.title: InlineSimpleMethods makes a semantic change in ES2015+
node.bodyHTML:
Given the following input code:

class Holder {
    constructor() {
        this.val = {internal: true};
        this.context =  {getVal: () => this.val}
    }
}

console.log(new Holder().context.getVal().internal);

Outputs:

class a {
  constructor() {
    this.g = {h:!0};
    this.i = {j:() => this.g};
  }
}
console.log((new a).i.g.h);

The InlineSimpleMethods replaces the call of getVal() with val, which is incorrect because the this in the definition of getVal is not context, but rather Holder.
This is not a problem in ES5, because the arrow function is already rewritten before running this pass.

pullRequest.title: Preserve parentheses on spread operator's AssignmentExpression

nodes.message:
Apply jscomp_java_library macro to //third_party/java_src/jscomp/java/com/google/debugging/sourcemap

PiperOrigin-RevId: 346618927
Preserve parentheses on spread operator's AssignmentExpression

node.title: Incorrect removal of parentheses
node.bodyHTML:
Closure Compiler sometimes incorrectly removes semantically important parentheses.

example.js:

function spreadSet() {
    var _a;
    return [...(_a = new Set([1]), (_a !== null && _a !== void 0 ? _a : []))];
}
console.log(spreadSet());
$ java -jar closure-compiler-v20201102.jar --compilation_level ADVANCED_OPTIMIZATIONS --formatting PRETTY_PRINT --language_out=ECMASCRIPT_2015 --js_output_file=bug.js example.js && cat bug.js && node bug.js
'use strict';
console.log(function() {
  var a;
  return [...a = new Set([1]), null !== a && void 0 !== a ? a : []];
}());

[ 1, Set(1) { 1 } ]

Notice the difference to just running the original script directly:

$ node example.js
[ 1 ]

While the input syntax may seem odd, it is the result of TypeScript+tsickle running on the following ES2020->ES2017 code:

function spreadSet() {
    return [...(new Set([1]) ?? [])];
}

console.log(spreadSet());

The incorrect behavior can also be observed in this simpler-to-read code, though it does throw a suspicious code warning:

console.log(...([1], [2])); // 2

Incorrect emit:

console.log(...[1], [2]); // 1 [ 2 ]

When outputting to ES5 the bug is not observed.

node.title: closure-compiler.jar includes unshaded dependencies
node.bodyHTML:
The latest (v20201102) closure-compiler.jar includes unshaded dependencies, which causes trouble -- they might be used in preference to the version we would prefer to use and cause breakage at runtime.

Browsing the file listing, I see these:

org/kohsuke/args4j
org/apache/tools

I believe a simple update to rules.jarjar would shade them. I'm happy to send that CR if you agree with my diagnosis.
Thanks

node.title: --json_streams `source_map` input is asymmetrical from `sourceMap` output
node.bodyHTML:
Coming from #3801

The input json on stdIn uses the format: [{sourceMap:""}]
Whereas the output json on stdOut uses: [{source_map:""}]
And the documentation says it is: [{srcmap:""}]

pullRequest.title: Automatically inject the extern definition for a dynamic import alias

mergeCommit.message:
Merge pull request #3830 from ChadKillingsworth:import-alias-inject

PiperOrigin-RevId: 384505306

nodes.message:
Propagate all source typenames in the debug info of Colors to improve debugability.

Previously, only a single name was propagated from one of the many JSTypes that may form the definition of a Color. Now, all names, up to string-equality are available.

Additionally, filenames are no longer propagated, but string representations of anonymous types are.

On the Color side, these names are collapsed into a single string with special formatting, to avoid API friction around modeling sets of sets. This same friction is part of the reason filenames are no longer present.

PiperOrigin-RevId: 384492951
Switch to Guava Splitter and update to new synthetic externs methods

pullRequest.title: Skip devirtualization of @nocollapse prototype methods

node.title: @nocollapse is not honored by DevirtualizePrototypeMethods
node.bodyHTML:
As discussed here, compiler seems to not work properly when using @nocollapse JSDoc tag. The compiler is properly not collapsing objects attributes but is sometimes collapsing objects prototypes when using the tag.

Example of code before compilation :

/** @constructor */
function MyClass() = { // Some code }
/** @nocollapse */
MyClass.someAttribute = function(someParam) { // Some code };
/** @nocollapse */
MyClass.prototype.someFunc = function() { // Some code calling someOtherFunc };
/** @nocollapse */
MyClass.prototype.someOtherFunc = function(someParam) { // Some code };

Example of code after compilation :

function MyCompiledClass = { // Some code }
MyCompiledClass.someCompiledAttribute = function(someParam) { // Some code };
MyCompiledClass.prototype.someCompiledFunc = function() { // Some code calling someOtherFunc }
function someOtherCompiledFunc(that, someParam) = { // Some code }

I've tried to set @this and @preserve tags without success. Using @export is not a good solution.

Compiler flags are :

  • compilation_level : 'ADVANCED'
  • warning_level : 'QUIET'
  • language_in : 'ECMASCRIPT5_STRICT'

Google-Closure-Compiler versions tested :

  • v20160315
  • v20170218
  • master at ee44867

pullRequest.title: Remove shaded content and restore dependency list to unshaded maven artifact

node.title: unshaded jar contains Apache Ant, GSON, etc.
node.bodyHTML:
Reported by Dominic in https://groups.google.com/g/closure-compiler-discuss/c/5ofdcVdWgQs

The unshaded jar should not contain copies of dependencies. Instead it should use dependencies from Maven. Copying the important details here:

These commands will show you some of the copies included in the latest release:

jar tf ~/.m2/repository/com/google/javascript/closure-compiler-unshaded/v20211107/closure-compiler-unshaded-v20211107.jar | grep 'apache'
jar tf ~/.m2/repository/com/google/javascript/closure-compiler-unshaded/v20211107/closure-compiler-unshaded-v20211107.jar | grep 'gson'

closure-compiler-unshaded-v20200927.jar was the first release that includes the apache dependencies in the unshaded jar. The gson dependencies have existed since even before that.

The commits in between v20200920 and v20200927 are v20200920...v20200927

Perhaps commit c9f3d32 introduced this problem?

pullRequest.title: Fix useless tests for LiveVariablesAnalysis

nodes.message:
Add DevirtualizeMethods tests for static class fields.

PiperOrigin-RevId: 465131874
Tweak comment

node.title: Potentially incorrect/useless test case for LiveVariablesAnalysis
node.bodyHTML:
TL;DR: a test doesn't appear to verify anything useful. No impact on users.

Hi, I was recently looking at the tests for LiveVariablesAnalysis and came across some test cases that appear to be incorrect/useless.

closure-compiler/test/com/google/javascript/jscomp/LiveVariablesAnalysisTest.java

Lines 360 to 368 in 1b7b32d

@Test
public void testArgumentsArray_doesNotEscape_destructuredParams() {
// These cases also cover a crash related to assuming all RESTs have a NAME child.
assertNotEscaped("function f([a]) { arguments; }", "a");
assertNotEscaped("function f([a] = []) { arguments; }", "a");
assertNotEscaped("function f(...[a]) { arguments; }", "a");
assertNotEscaped("function f({a}) { arguments; }", "a");
assertNotEscaped("function f({a} = {}) { arguments; }", "a");
}

The assertions appear to test that various destructuring parameters aren't escaped by references to the arguments array. However, the params in the input code will never be considered escaped because they, and the arguments references, are in nested functions; The inputs contain a function e.g. function f([a]) { arguments; } but are then wrapped in another function by computeLiveness:

closure-compiler/test/com/google/javascript/jscomp/LiveVariablesAnalysisTest.java

Lines 677 to 678 in 1b7b32d

src =
(async ? "async " : "") + "function _FUNCTION(param1, param2 = 1, ...param3){" + src + "}";

which then configures ControlFlowAnalysis to not visit nested functions (note the lack of builder.setTraverseFunctions(true)):

closure-compiler/test/com/google/javascript/jscomp/LiveVariablesAnalysisTest.java

Lines 691 to 696 in 1b7b32d

ControlFlowGraph<Node> cfg =
ControlFlowAnalysis.builder()
.setCompiler(compiler)
.setCfgRoot(n)
.setIncludeEdgeAnnotations(true)
.computeCfg();

This means that the params will never be escaped because:

  1. The arguments references are never visited during data flow analysis, so markAllParametersEscaped is never called.
  2. Even if markAllParametersEscaped were called, the outer params (param1, param2, param3) would be escaped, not the inner params (a).

The issue can be shown by adding the following test cases to LiveVariablesAnalysisTest.java:

assertNotEscaped("function f(a) { arguments; }", "a");
   assertEscaped("function f(a) { arguments; }", "a");

The param a should be escaped because it's a NAME param, and therefore assertNotEscaped should fail and assertEscaped should pass, but the reverse happens.

One way to resolve this would be to add an alternate assertNotEscaped helper function that doesn't wrap the input in a function. I believe this would correct the tests so they verify the intended behaviour.

If you agree with the above, I'm happy to open a PR to explore the aforementioned fix.

pullRequest.title: Adjust types for crypto.getRandomValues

mergeCommit.message:
Merge pull request #3906 from LiviaMedeiros:adjust-getRandomValues-v2

PiperOrigin-RevId: 421862673

nodes.message:
Internal change

PiperOrigin-RevId: 421855236

Adjust types for crypto.getRandomValues

The union type is "any `TypedArray` but not `Float32Array` nor `Float64Array`" according to specifications.

node.title: Wrong types in Crypto.getRandomValues
node.bodyHTML:
The "real life" problem:

const randomBinaryString8 = String.fromCharCode(...crypto.getRandomValues(new Uint16Array(4)));
console.log(randomBinaryString8);
$ java -jar closure-compiler-v20220104.jar -O ADVANCED -W VERBOSE --formatting PRETTY_PRINT --language_out ECMASCRIPT_NEXT good.js
good.js:1:51: WARNING - [JSC_TYPE_MISMATCH] Spread operator only applies to Iterable types
found   : ArrayBufferView
required: Iterable
  1| const randomBinaryString8 = String.fromCharCode(...crypto.getRandomValues(new Uint16Array(4)));
                                                        ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

0 error(s), 1 warning(s), 100.0% typed
const a = String.fromCharCode(...crypto.getRandomValues(new Uint16Array(4)));
console.log(a);

Also a problem:

const throwme = crypto.getRandomValues(new DataView(new ArrayBuffer(8))); // obvious TypeMismatchError
console.log(throwme);
$ java -jar closure-compiler-v20220104.jar -O ADVANCED -W VERBOSE --formatting PRETTY_PRINT --language_out ECMASCRIPT_NEXT bad.js
const a = crypto.getRandomValues(new DataView(new ArrayBuffer(8)));
console.log(a);

The reason:

closure-compiler thinks that Crypto.getRandomValues takes and returns generic ArrayBufferView, which:

  • doesn't implement everything TypedArray has, e.g. array methods
  • can be Float##Array or even DataView

According to W3C docs, it must throw TypeMismatchError if argument isn't an integer-based (well, or bigint-based) array.
According to MDN docs, it takes and returns integer-based TypedArray as well.

Proposed solution:

diff --git a/externs/browser/w3c_webcrypto.js b/externs/browser/w3c_webcrypto.js
--- a/externs/browser/w3c_webcrypto.js
+++ b/externs/browser/w3c_webcrypto.js
@@ -796,8 +796,8 @@ webCrypto.Crypto = function() {};
 
 /**
  * @see https://developer.mozilla.org/en/DOM/window.crypto.getRandomValues
- * @param {!ArrayBufferView} typedArray
- * @return {!ArrayBufferView}
+ * @param {!TypedArray} typedArray
+ * @return {!TypedArray}
  * @throws {Error}
  */
 webCrypto.Crypto.prototype.getRandomValues = function(typedArray) {};

Or in ugly way to raise warning for Float32Array and Float64Array (totes uncommon mistake):

- * @param {!ArrayBufferView} typedArray
- * @return {!ArrayBufferView}
+ * @param {!Int8Array|!Uint8Array|!Uint8ClampedArray|!Int16Array|!Uint16Array|!Int32Array|!Uint32Array|!BigInt64Array|!BigUint64Array} typedArray
+ * @return {!Int8Array|!Uint8Array|!Uint8ClampedArray|!Int16Array|!Uint16Array|!Int32Array|!Uint32Array|!BigInt64Array|!BigUint64Array}

PR for any of these is ready to be opened.

pullRequest.title: Allow URL objects in methods expecting a url-string

mergeCommit.message:
Merge pull request #3920 from LiviaMedeiros:patch-urlstring

PiperOrigin-RevId: 448258686

nodes.message:
Merge pull request #3939 from treblereel:MediaQueryListEvent

PiperOrigin-RevId: 448258664
Allow URL objects in more methods expecting a url-string

node.title: url params are not accepting URL objects
node.bodyHTML:
A lot of networking methods in JS are accepting any stringable objects as url-string arguments.

const amStringable = {toString: () => 'https://example.com'};
fetch(amStringable).then(response => console.log(response.url)); // 'https://example.com/' if fetched

/* closure-compiler warns:
WARNING - [JSC_TYPE_MISMATCH] actual parameter 1 of fetch does not match formal parameter
found   : {}
required: (Request|string)
*/

Most implementations are de facto omnivorous: browsers are casting everything to strings and in case of error happily use undefined, null and [object%20Object]. Usually this is an undesirable outcome, and closure-compiler saves the day with strict typechecking for strings only.

However, URL objects should be acceptable.
Aside from other advantages over raw strings, these objects come with validation and proper encodings. Using them directly as parameters would reinforce safety.

Therefore, I propose replacing string with !URL|string in externs, whenever method expects an url-string and allows such objects.
